title: On how things got here
excerpt: From SKGChess and this page to the decision to make a game and share the process publicly.
content:
To understand how I got here, I need to start in November 2024, when I began working on the project SKGChess.

At that time, my focus was clear: become a better engineer. In my mind, that meant better work positions, and better positions meant more success. I work as a software engineer and I respect my field. Back then, that respect alone was enough to give meaning to the effort.

When I chose to build a chess app, the decision was not only practical. I already liked chess, so it made sense from a motivation standpoint. But there was something else present. Even though my main framework was professional growth, I was beginning to look for something that meant more personally.

I had just started feeling that working as a software engineer provided personal meaning and professional growth, but it did not feel like it had a meaningful social impact. It did not allow me to interact with people in a way that felt connected to something larger than myself.

For the first time, I felt the need for my work to express me personally and to carry some form of social meaning. Chess is not only something I like, but something I have communicated openly about with other people and analyzed for hours. Chess is not isolated. It is played with others. It exists between people. Much like I play games and connect with others on well-known chess platforms, I understood that building a chess app meant creating something that could enter that same shared space. It would exist in interaction.

These thoughts led me to work on SKGChess for nearly 10 months. What started as a small self-improvement project gradually became something much bigger than I initially expected. It was no longer just practice. It became commitment.

After finishing SKGChess, I also launched this page, ixlstudio.com — not in its current form, but as an attempt at freelancing. The intention was still professional positioning. Build something. Present it. Move forward.

Completing both made something clear.

I had created something that I was genuinely proud of. I gave my aesthetics. I made deliberate decisions. They reflected discipline and care. They expressed a part of me.

But they are rather limited in what they can express. They cannot fully express what I think and what I value.

That gap stayed with me.

If these did not fully express me, then working purely as an employee would not either — at least not in the way I need. Employment has value. Personal relationships at work have value. Employment sustains life. But usefulness alone is not enough for me.

I want to feel connected through my work.

Over the past months, I took a step back.

I questioned whether creation needed to remain central. I considered shifting my focus toward simply enjoying life.

During that time, I went back and forth. I began thinking more seriously about creating a game, since it felt like a logical continuation of engineering. It would still involve technical structure, but it would also allow space for expression.

I questioned whether this idea was based only on interest or whether it was something I genuinely needed in order to express myself. I acknowledged that liking games alone is not enough reason to make one. Enjoyment is not the same as necessity. I wanted to understand whether I genuinely needed to express ideas through this medium, or whether I was only attracted to the idea of making a game. I examined how much of it was curiosity, how much was ambition, and how much was expression.

Even after questioning it from different angles, the idea kept returning: making a game.

Which brings me to today.

I now feel ready to take this idea seriously. Not as a casual experiment, but as a committed project. I want to approach it with full professional seriousness — not as a hobby or a side project — while at the same time allowing it to carry personal meaning.

I do not want to separate professionalism from authenticity. I do not want to choose between advancing my skills and expressing something that reflects who I am.

In that sense, choosing to pursue game creation is not a rejection of engineering. But an expansion of it.

At the same time, I want to share the entire process publicly. Not only the final game, but the decisions, the doubts, the adjustments, and the learning.

In this way, the process itself becomes the connection I am searching for with people, not just the finished game.

If you want to follow this process — the creation of the game and the documentation of its internal decisions and thoughts — you can find it on the home page under the name “Changing Ways.”

Thank you for reading.
